Individual Service Report of Major Walter Reed, Surg. U.S.A. for
the fiscal year ended June 30, 1895.

STATION Washington, D.C.
DATE June 30, 1895.

TO THE Surg. General, U.S.A.
Washington, D.C.

SIR: I have the honor to report that during the year 1894-5 my station and duties were as follows:
From July 1st, 1894, to June 30, 1895,

EFFICIENCY REPORT OF Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U.S. Army.
for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1895.

Washington, D.C.

1. During the year ending June 30, 1895, this officer was
(a) Attached to this {command}
{station} from July 1 1894, to June 30, 1895
(b) In arrest days.
(c) Tried by court-martial. Give charges briefly, source, number and date of the order promulga-
ting the proceedings and result of the trial if known
(d) Absent sick days. State disease and whether or not contracted in line of duty.
(e) Present sick or on sick report days. State disease, and whether or not con-
tracted in line of duty

2. General statement, without dates, of more important routine duties performed Curator
Army Medical Museum, Surgeon General's Office.

3. What duties other than those of routine were performed by him? Delegate to the annual
meeting of the American Medical Association, Baltimore, Md
Member of a board for the examination of Medical Officers
4. Habits, general conduct and bearing Excellent
5. Professional zeal and ability Excellent
6. The condition and discipline of men under his immediate control Good
7. Capacity for command Good

8. Has he any peculiar fitness or marked ability for staff duties, or other details? Especially
well qualified for his present duties
9. Should he be intrusted with important duties requiring discretion and judgment? Yes

10. Has he been specially mentioned, favorably or unfavorably, in official reports of commanding officers?
If yes, give reference to reports No

11. Is he qualified mentally, morally and physically for all the duties of his position? If no, in what
respect is he deficient? He is.
(OVER.)

Remarks: A competent and reliable medical officer with
scientific tastes and acquirements. An excellent pathologist.

I certify that the entries herein made are true and impartial, to the best of my knowledge and belief. I
have communicated unfavorable mention as directed.

G.M. Sternberg
Surgeon General
U.S. Army.

NOTE.--In answer to queries 4, 5, 6, and 7, degrees of efficiency will be expressed as “excellent,” “good,” “toler-
able,” or “not good.” Whenever an officer is marked “not good.” the reason for such answer must be clearly stated,
and a copy of that portion of the report will be furnished to the officer concerned, who will be granted a reasonable time
to prepare such written statement in respect thereto as he may desire to make; this statement will be indorsed and
forwarded with the report. Should the officer not desire to make a statement, that fact will be noted. If in arrest,
the cause, if known, and name of officer ordering the arrest will be stated. Under the head of “Remarks,” any appro-
priate explanations may be made for which other allotted spaces are insufficient.
